title: SMIME certificate still available after removal
content:
Hi all,

for signing PDFs with my SMIME certificate, another 3rd party software (LibreOffice) uses the Thunderbird profile folder (nssdb stored which is located there). After some investigation by myself, it could be a problem within Thunderbird certificate management itself.

Situation: I've a current and some outdated SMIME certificates for my mail address. But all for one mail address.

Because the current SMIME certificate is not accessible for LibreOffice, I removed temporary all of my outdated SMIME certificates from Thunderbird by the builtin certificate management, i.e. the list of my personal certificates was set to one entry (=the current certificate) in Thunderbird. But even then, LibreOffice lists only an outdated certificate (which is not visible anymore in the Thunderbird builtin certificate management).

Therefore I've checked with certutil the nssdb entries in the Thunderbird profile folder. Surprisingly, there is an outdated SMIME to my mail address contained (no further, even not the current one). Even after removal of those outdated certificates via the builtin certificate management. The current certificate is never listed; always only an outdated one.

This looks like a difference between builtin certificate management and nssdb within the profile folder (or may for another storage location of the certificates)?

certutil -L -d ~/.thunderbird/myprofilefolder --email mymailaddress

Thanks in advance!

Environment OS: Ubuntu 24.04.2 LTS Thunderbird: 128.12.0esr (64-Bit)
creator: Snowbiker

title: Third party software opening Thunderbird emails as non-formattable
content:
I have a brand new computer with a brand new installation of Thunderbird. The email account is set up correctly and emails can be sent and received.

The computer also runs Cashflow Manager which can email invoices and statements. When we attempt to send an email from Cashflow Manger, a new Thunderbird email window opens up but it appears to be in a non-formattable state. You can't write in it or do anything with it. You have go to the file options and do "Open As New Message" to then be able to do anything with it.

Why are new emails opened in this manner different to opening them from within Thunderbird itself?
creator: info5587

title: Ordering of folders in Local Folders
content:
Thunderbird 140.0 (64-bit)

I cannot reorder some folders within my Local Folders. It only happens with some folders - =not all of them. I can drag and drop the folder to the location I want but for some folders one of the following things happen.

1. The folder immediately return to its original location, that is, I can't move it at all or 2. I cannot drop it where I want but I can drop it in a nearby location and then shuffle the folders around it so it ends up where I want it. For example, if I want to put folder Y between folder X and Z, I can't drop it in that location but I can drop it before folder X (or after folder Z, or in any other nearby location) and then move other folders around so I end up with the correct X,Y,Z order.

In ALL cases, when I exit Thunderbird and then restart it, the folders re-appear in their previous locations - that is, as if I hadn't moved them at all.

This only happens with some folders - and not necessarily the same folders each time - sometimes folders which were in their correct location re-appear somewhere else, but this is a rare event and I've only observed it a couple of times. I have disabled 3rd party backup software in case this was reverse synchronising the files - it was putting the old versions back (a long shot!) but the problem persists.

I have done a clean re-install and are using the default locations provided during the installation.

I could try to create new folders, move the emails to those folders, delete the existing offending folders and then rename the new folders to the desired names and then try move them to the desired locations but this is just a hack and maybe it won't work.
creator: richarda01

title: Thunderbird is sending "whitelisted" emails to my spam folder
content: I use Thunderbird on a MacBook Air running Sequoia. In the last month or so, Thunderbird has taken to sending emails to my spam folder when it shouldn't. To clarify: I am aware Thunderbird does not have its own whitelisting process, but makes use of address books. All the addresses recently characterised as spam are listed in my basic address book, Mac OS's proprietary "Contacts"; most of the emails were from private correspondents, and as far as I can tell included no spam trigger phrases such as "special offer"! If this problem is insoluble, or inherent to the application, I will be forced to abandon Thunderbird, which is otherwise perfectly satisfactory. Any suggestions?

title: Installing a stubborn email account
content:
I have a Suddenlink.net email account that I can't seem to install. Suddenlink has been purchased by Optimum. I have all the requirements that Optimum has given, but it still won't load. my email address is dluenser@suddenlink.net. My password is correct because I can go to their site and get my emails. These are the requirements that they gave me. Again, it is a suddenlink account. Can you help? I've tried numerous times to work with Optimum techs, but they are not knowledgeable to what I should do.

Server Settings by Domain Use the following server settings to set up most third-party email clients or applications to send or receive Optimum email. IMAP (Inbound) Optimum incoming mail server: mail.optimum.net Suddenlink incoming mail server: imap.suddenlink.net Incoming mail port (SSL): 993 (Secure Connection. Recommended if your mail client supports) POP (Inbound) Optimum incoming mail server: mail.optimum.net Suddenlink incoming mail server: pop.suddenlink.net Incoming mail port (SSL): 995 (Secure Connection. Recommended if your mail client supports)

SMTP (Outbound) Optimum outgoing mail server: mail.optimum.net Suddenlink outgoing mail server: smtp.suddenlink.net Outgoing mail port (SSL): 465 (Secure Connection. Recommended if your mail client supports) • Check My SMTP server requires authentication Username and Password (if needed) User Name: Your full email address, including the @domain.net at the end (i.e. @optimum.net, @suddenlink.net) Password: The password for your particular email address • Outgoing server verification/authentication must be enabled and on. If your email client has the option or checkbox that says My outgoing server requires authentication this will need to be checked along with use same settings as my incoming mail server.

Hi all,

Details: •⁠ ⁠When I send an email, it doesn’t appear in the Sent folder in Thunderbird - sometimes it does thou. •⁠ ⁠Sometimes sent emails don’t appear even in Gmail’s web Sent folder. •⁠ ⁠I have checked my account settings, and the Sent folder is mapped correctly. •⁠ ⁠I use Thunderbird version: Version 140.0esr on Sequoia 15.5. •⁠ ⁠I don’t see an Outbox folder in Thunderbird. •⁠ ⁠Sometimes I get errors related to folder sync (like “folder in use” message).

What I tried: •⁠ ⁠Restarted Thunderbird •⁠ ⁠Checked folder subscriptions and synchronization •⁠ ⁠Verified Gmail IMAP settings •⁠ ⁠Sent test emails to other accounts — same issue persists

I’d appreciate any tips on how to ensure sent emails are saved and visible in Thunderbird’s Sent folder and on Gmail!

thanks

title: Backup e ripristino PC email
content: Ho fatto un backup di Thunderbird copiando integralmente la cartella Thunderbird posta nella cartella appdata\roaming\thunderbird presente nel profilo del utente Windows. Successivamente dopo aver installato, su altro PC, il Thunderbird, ho ricopiato la cartella precedentemente salvata nella nuova posizione appdata\roaming\thunderbird. Al successivo riavvio di Thunderbird, vengono correttamente visualizzate e disponibili tutti gli archivi dei profili della posta. . Una voluta, però, chiusa e riavviato Thunderbird non viene visualizzati nessun email collegato ai profili. Come posso risolvere il problema ?
